questions.text: After normal vaginal delivery of a healthy fetus, control cord traction was done to help remove the placenta from the uterus. Gross examination of the placenta is similar to the image given below. Which of the following is true regarding the placenta in the image below?

choices.text: Fetal surface is rough and covered with amnion.
Maternal surface is rough and contains cotyledons.
Maternal surface is rough and covered with amnion
Fetal surface is smooth and contains cotyledons

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Maternal surface is rough and contains cotyledons

 

Explanation:

The placenta has 2 surfaces:

Maternal surface (Basal plate)

Fetal surface (Chorionic plate)
  • Adherent to the uterine wall.
  • It is rough, dull, and dark red in color
  • It is divided into cotyledons by decidual septum.
  • It helps anchor the placenta to the uterus.
  • Contains maternal blood sinus.
  • Receives blood from spiral arteries.
  • The umbilical cord is attached to the fetal surface.
  • It is smooth, shiny and bluish-purple.
  • It is covered with amnion.
  • Takes part in gaseous and nutritional exchange.
  • Highly vascular with fetal capillaries.
  • Facilitates nutritional exchange via chorionic villi.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida experiences severe abdominal pain, bradycardia, and sudden hypotension immediately after the delivery of the placenta. On examination, a round, reddish-purple mass is seen protruding from the vagina. What is the most appropriate immediate management?

choices.text: Administer oxytocin and perform uterine massage
Manually replace the uterus and administer tocolytics
Apply warm compresses and wait for a spontaneous reduction

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Manually replace the uterus and administer tocolytics.

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario suggests acute uterine inversion, a rare but life-threatening obstetric emergency that can be caused by :
    • Excessive traction on the umbilical cord during placental delivery.
    • Fundal pressure before placental separation.
    • Inherent weakness of the uterine wall.
    • Placenta accreta or percreta.
    • Short umbilical cord.
  • It presents with sudden severe lower abdominal pain, heavy vaginal bleeding, a visible or palpable vaginal mass, absent uterine fundus on palpation, and signs of shock including tachycardia and hypotension.
  • Management includes immediate manual replacement (repositioning) of the uterus by administering tocolytics (e.g., terbutaline, nitroglycerin) to help relax the uterus for easier repositioning.
  • Classification:
    • First degree: Fundus of the uterus collapsed but hasn’t come through the cervix.
    • Second degree: Fundus protrudes through the cervical os.
    • Third degree: Fundus protrudes to or beyond the introitus.
    • Fourth degree: Both the uterus and vagina protrude outside the introitus.

 

Administer oxytocin and perform uterine massage (Option A): Oxytocin and massage will cause the uterus to contract, making repositioning more difficult and potentially worsening the inversion.

Perform immediate hysterectomy (Option C): While hysterectomy may be necessary in severe, irreducible cases, it's not the first-line treatment. Repositioning should be attempted first.

Apply warm compresses and wait for spontaneous reduction (Option D) : Uterine inversion is an emergency requiring immediate intervention. Waiting for spontaneous reduction is dangerous and can lead to severe haemorrhage and shock.

questions.text: A 32-year-old multiparous woman has just delivered a healthy baby boy vaginally. The obstetrician is now managing the third stage of labour and is observing for signs of placental separation. Which of the following signs is the most definitive sign of placental separation?

choices.text: Permanent lengthening of the umbilical cord
A gush of blood from the vagina

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Permanent lengthening of the umbilical cord

Explanation:

When the placenta detaches from the uterine wall, it descends towards the birth canal, pulling on the umbilical cord and causing it to visibly lengthen outside the vagina. This is considered to be the most reliable sign of placental separation.

A gush of blood from the vagina (Option B): This is often seen, especially in the Schultze method of separation, but it's not the surest sign. Some blood loss can occur before complete separation.

Rising of the uterine fundus (Option C): This sign, also known as the 'rising sign', suggests placental separation but can be affected by factors like bladder fullness or uterine tone.

Uterus becoming firm and globular (Option D): The uterus becoming firm and globular during the third stage of labour indicates uterine contraction and preparation for placental expulsion. It is the earliest sign of placental separation.

questions.text: Which of the following methods of placental separation is characterised by a sudden gush of blood, followed by the shiny part of placenta appearing at the vulva?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Schultze method

Explanation:

The Schultze method is the most common method of placental separation, occurring in about 80% of deliveries.

  • In this method, placental separation initiates at the centre of the placenta, leading to the formation of a retroplacental hematoma as detachment progresses.
  • The placenta descends through the birth canal, undergoing inversion, resulting in the fetal surface presenting first (Shiny part of Placenta).
  • A distinctive feature of this method of placental separation is a sudden gush of blood upon complete detachment from the uterine wall.
  • As the placenta emerges, it resembles an inverted umbrella at the vulva, with its maternal surface facing outward.

Duncan method(Option B): In this method, the placenta separates from the periphery and descends sideways, maintaining its disc shape. Bleeding is slow and steady, and the maternal surface appears first at the vulva

Manual removal(Option C)​​​​​​: This method involves manual intervention by the obstetrician to detach and remove the placenta when it fails to separate and deliver naturally. It is used in cases of retained placenta or when other delivery methods are unsuccessful.

Crede manoeuvre(Option D): This technique uses fundal pressure to deliver the placenta but is no longer recommended due to risks of incomplete separation, retained fragments, and complications like hemorrhage and infection.

questions.text: During a routine ultrasound in a pregnant woman at 20 weeks gestation, a single umbilical artery (SUA) is identified. Which of the following conditions is most commonly associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cardiovascular anomalies

Explanation:

Cardiovascular and genitourinary anomalies are the most common congenital anomalies associated with a Single Umbilical Artery (SUA).

Single Uterine artery:

  • SUA is often associated with significant malformations, prompting targeted sonography and especially fetal echocardiography.
  • Common associated anomalies are cardiovascular (such as Ventricular septal defect (VSD), AtrioVentricular septal defect (AVSD), and hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS)) and genitourinary abnormalities.
  • SUA increases the risk of aneuploidy, such as trisomy 18 and 13; amniocentesis for karyotype assessment is recommended.
  • Isolated SUA in low-risk pregnancies significantly increases fetal growth restriction and perinatal death; hence, clinical growth monitoring is recommended.

Gastrointestinal anomalies (Option B): While less common than cardiovascular anomalies, gastrointestinal defects are also associated with SUA, including conditions like omphalocele, gastroschisis, and intestinal atresia.

Skeletal anomalies (Option C):  Skeletal defects associated with SUA include limb reductions and vertebral anomalies, though they are less common than cardiovascular and genitourinary anomalies.

Neural tube defects (Option D):  Neural tube defects, such as spina bifida and anencephaly, are least commonly associated with SUA.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 32 weeks gestation presents with painless vaginal bleeding. An earlier ultrasound showed a low-lying placenta, and the non-stress test revealed a sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern with a heart rate of 100 bpm. Maternal vital signs are stable. What is the most appropriate test to determine the source of the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Alkaline denaturation test

Explanation:

An alkaline denaturation test distinguishes fetal blood from maternal blood, as fetal blood is more resistant to denaturation by alkali or acid.

  • The clinical scenario of a low-lying placenta, sinusoidal fetal heart rate pattern, and a fetal heart rate of 100 bpm raises suspicion for Vasa Previa.
  • This condition involves fetal blood vessels traversing the membranes over the cervix, unprotected by the placenta or umbilical cord, posing a significant risk of fetal haemorrhage.
  • These vessels can tear during cervical dilation or membrane rupture, leading to rapid fetal blood loss.
  • Vasa previa is of two types:
    • Type 1: Vessels are part of a velamentous cord insertion.
    • Type 2: Vessels span between parts of a bilobate or succenturiate placenta.
    • An Alkaline denaturation test, or Apt test, is the most appropriate test to distinguish fetal blood loss from maternal blood loss.

Kleihauer-Betke test (Option A) detects fetal red blood cells in the maternal circulation, which helps in diagnosing fetomaternal haemorrhage in Rh isoimmunisation.

Doppler ultrasound(Option B) is valuable in diagnosing vasa previa by visualising fetal vessels over the cervix, but it does not determine whether the bleeding is fetal or maternal once it has occurred.

Fetal fibronectin test (Option C) is used to predict the risk of preterm labour by detecting fetal fibronectin in vaginal secretions. It has no role in identifying the source of vaginal bleeding.

questions.text: A 32-year-old G2P1 woman at 37 weeks of gestation presents to the emergency department with painless vaginal bleeding. Her vital signs are stable, and fetal heart tones are reassuring. An ultrasound performed earlier in the pregnancy indicated placenta previa. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Give IV steroids and Rest in a High-Risk Ward
PV examination was done in OT

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Emergency cesarean section

Explanation:

The most appropriate next step in management for the given clinical scenario is to deliver the fetus via cesarean section.

Placenta Previa:

Placenta previa occurs when the placenta implants in the lower uterine segment, covering or nearing the internal cervical os.

Symptoms: Only presentation is painless vaginal bleeding.

 

 

Management:

 

This patient has active bleeding and is at term. Observation in a high-risk ward is only considered for minor bleeding before 34 weeks of gestation. As this patient is at term, a cesarean section is the best option (Option A)

 

Normal delivery is contraindicated in placenta previa as the placenta is delivered first, which causes fetal hypoxia and fetal death and also leads to postpartum haemorrhage in the mother (Option B)

 

Per vaginal examination, is contraindicated in this case of placenta previa as it can further precipitate bleeding (Option D)

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 20 weeks of gestation presents for a routine anatomy ultrasound. During the scan, the sonographer visualises the umbilical cord and comments on its normal appearance and structure. Which of the following is true regarding the normal umbilical cord?

choices.text: It contains two veins and two arteries.
It directly connects to the maternal bloodstream.
The right umbilical vein persists, while the left umbilical vein disappears early in fetal development.
The umbilical artery converts into the medial umbilical ligament.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) The umbilical artery converts into the medial umbilical ligament.

 

Explanation:

Normal Umbilical cord:

  • The umbilical Cord connects the fetal umbilicus to the centre of the placental chorionic plate. (Option B)
  • The umbilical cord typically contains two arteries and one vein (Option A is ruled out), with the right umbilical vein disappearing early (by the 12th week), leaving the left vein behind (Option C is ruled out).
  • Oxygenated blood flows from the umbilical vein to the fetus via the ductus venosus (to the inferior vena cava) or smaller hepatic circulation openings.
  • Deoxygenated blood exits the fetus through two umbilical arteries, which become medial umbilical ligaments after birth. (Option D)
  • The umbilical cord connects the fetal circulation to the placenta, facilitating the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products. Maternal and fetal blood systems remain separate, with the exchange occurring through the placental barrier. (Option B is ruled out).
  • Wharton's jelly is a primitive mucous connective tissue found between the amniotic epithelium and the umbilical vessels. Its primary function is to cushion, protect, and support the umbilical vessels.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the most common developmental anomaly of the placenta?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Placenta previa

Explanation:

Placenta previa, or low-lying placenta, is the most commonly occurring developmental anomaly of the placenta.

Abnormalities of Placenta:

Condition

Description

Succenturiate placenta

(Option A)

 
  • Extra lobes form separate from the main placental body within the membranes, connected to it by fetal vessels and membranes.
  • It occurs only in 5 % of placentas

Bilobed Placenta

 

Placenta with two roughly equal lobes separated by a membrane.

Placenta accreta spectrum

(Option C)

 
  • Occurs when the placenta is abnormally adherent to the uterine wall after childbirth.
  • The spectrum has 3 conditions:
    • Accreta
    • Increta
    • Percreta
  • It occurs in 1 out of 2500 pregnancies

Ring-shaped Placenta (Option D)

 

An annularly shaped placenta, often resembling a horseshoe due to partial atrophy, is rare.

Placenta Membranacea

 

A rare condition where chorionic villi cover fetal membranes either partially or completely, occupying the periphery of the chorion.

Circumvallate Placenta

Placenta with raised edges composed of chorion, amnion, and fibrin deposits and associated with poor pregnancy outcomes.

Circummarginate Placenta

Similar to the circumvallate placenta but with a flat transition from membranous to villous chorion.

Battledore Placenta

 
  • An umbilical cord is inserted at or near the placental margin rather than in the center.
  • It is associated with pregnancy complications like preterm labor and fetal distress.
Placenta spuria
  • Unequal placenta not connected by vessel

questions.text:
Match the following condition with its appropriate diagrammatic representation.


	
		
			
			Disorder 
			
			
			Figure 
			
		
		
			
			A.Accreta 
			
			
			1.
			
		
		
			
			B.Percreta 
			
			
			2.
			
		
		
			
			C.Increta 
			
			
			3.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) A-2, B-1, C-3

 

Explanation:

The Placenta accreta spectrum has conditions:

 

Placenta accreta spectrum

Description

Placenta accreta

Villi is firmly adherent to the myometrium

Placenta increta

Villi invades the myometrium

Placenta percreta

Villi penetrate through the myometrium and to or through the serosa.

questions.text: At approximately what gestational age is the development of the placenta generally completed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 12 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

Placental development, involving the formation of chorion frondosum (fetal component) and decidua basalis (maternal component), is typically completed by around the 12th week of gestation.

Day 11-13
  • Placental development begins with the blastocyst implanting into the uterine wall by day 11, leading to lacunar spaces and trabeculae forming by day 13.
  • Stem villi develop from trabeculae, establishing connections between the chorionic and basal plates.

Day 21
  • Villi develop arterio-capillary-venous systems that connect with the embryonic circulation via the body stalk.

3-4 weeks
  • Lacunar spaces merge to form intervillous spaces, which fill with maternal blood.

Week 6
  • The decidua capsularis begins to thin, while the chorion frondosum and decidua basalis undergo robust growth, culminating in the formation of the placenta by week 12.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman comes to the OPD for her regular antenatal visit in the second trimester. Her latest USG scan shows a placental thickness of 48 mm. Which of the following factors will not lead to the above finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Fetal growth restriction

Explanation:

Placentomegaly is defined as a placenta >40 mm in the 2nd trimester and >60 mm in the 3rd trimester

Fetal growth restriction, which is associated with uteroplacental insufficiency, can causea  small placenta.

Causes of placentomegaly and small placenta:

Placentomegaly

Small placenta / Placental insufficiency

  • Maternal
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Severe anaemia
  • Fetal
    • Parvovirus
    • Cytomegalovirus
    • Hydrops fetalis
    • Anemia
    • Syphilis
    • Toxoplasmosis
    • Molar pregnancy
  • Preeclampsia
  • Maternal hypertension
  • Maternal smoking
  • Use of cocaine
  • Advanced maternal age
  • Maternal alcohol consumption
  • Chromosomal anomalies (trisomies)

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct order of blood flow in placental circulation?

choices.text:
Maternal blood: umbilical artery → intervillous space;

Fetal blood: umbilical vein → chorionic villi

Maternal blood: spiral arteries → intervillous space;

Fetal blood: umbilical arteries → chorionic villi

Maternal blood: spiral arteries → umbilical vein;

Fetal blood: intervillous space → umbilical artery

Maternal blood: umbilical vein → chorionic villi;

Fetal blood: spiral arteries → intervillous space

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Maternal blood: spiral arteries → intervillous space; Fetal blood: umbilical arteries → chorionic villi

Explanation:

Placental circulation consists of two independent circulation systems.

  • Uteroplacental circulation
    • Maternal Blood flows from spiral arteries → uteroplacental arteries → intervillous space.
    • Trophoblast invasion transforms spiral arteries into low-resistance vessels, enhancing uterine blood flow and nutrient exchange.
  • Fetoplacental circulation
    • Fetal Blood flows from umbilical arteries → chorionic villi
  • Exchange of Nutrients: Maternal blood surrounds chorionic villi, facilitating nutrient and gas exchange.
  • Return to Fetus: Oxygenated blood returns to the fetus through the umbilical vein, completing the fetal-placental circulation loop.
  • Venous Drainage: Maternal blood exits via uterine veins after exchanging substances.

questions.text: Which of the following pairs of placental hormones and their function is incorrectly matched?

choices.text: Beta HCG - Maintains corpus luteum function
Human Placental Lactogen - Helps in maternal adaptation to fetal energy requirements.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) hGH-V - promotes placental growth

Explanation:

  • Human Growth Hormone Variant (hGH-V) that is not expressed in the pituitary is expressed in the placenta. It is synthesized in the syncytiotrophoblast. 
  • Levels of hGH-V in maternal plasma & those of insulin-like growth factor 1 positively correlate & also likely plays a role in mediating insulin resistance in pregnancy.
  • By regulating glucose & lipid metabolism in pregnancy & ensuring adequate nutrient supply to the fetus, it plays a role in promoting fetal growth.

Placental hormones

Extra placental sites of secretion

Functions

Human chorionic gonadotropin

(Option B)

  

Released exclusively from the placenta.
  • Maintains corpus luteum function
  • Regulates fetal testis testosterone secretion
  • Stimulate maternal thyroid secretion

Human Placental lactogen

(Option D)
  • Helps in maternal adaptation to fetal energy requirements

Inhibin

(Option A)

  

Ovaries/testis.
  • Inhibits FSH-mediated ovulation
  • Inhibin from placenta also regulates hCG synthesis.

 

  

Growth hormone hCG variant

Released exclusively from the placenta.
  • Mediates pregnancy insulin resistance.

questions.text: Which cell type in the placenta is primarily responsible for producing human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) and human placental lactogen (hPL)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Syncytiotrophoblasts

 

Explanation:

  • Syncytiotrophoblasts (derived from cytotrophoblasts) are specialised, multinucleated epithelial layers that cover villous trees and directly interact with maternal blood.
  • Hormones synthesised by syncytiotrophoblasts include hCG, hPL, progesterone, estrogens (estriol, estradiol), and relaxin.

  • Cytotrophoblasts: Differentiate into syncytiotrophoblasts; aid implantation and produce CRH, GnRH, TRH, GHRH.

  • Hofbauer cells: Fetal macrophages producing VEGF and proangiogenic factors for placental vasculogenesis.

  • Decidual cells: Maternal cells that support and nourish the embryo and placenta.

questions.text: Which glycoprotein is primarily localised in the chorion and decidua at the maternal-fetal interface?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Fibronectin

Explanation:

  • Fetal fibronectin (FFN) is a glycoprotein found at the maternal-fetal interface of the amniotic membranes, specifically binding between the chorion and decidua.
  • FFN levels measuring 50 ng/mL or higher in cervicovaginal discharge from 22 -34 weeks strongly predict spontaneous preterm birth. This biomarker is highly regarded for its predictive accuracy across diverse populations.

  • Laminin (Option A): A basal lamina glycoprotein involved in cell adhesion and signaling; not primarily localized at the maternal-fetal interface.

  • Collagen (Option C): A structural protein in connective tissue; present in the placenta but not a glycoprotein mainly at the maternal-fetal interface.

  • Integrin (Option D): Cell surface receptors involved in tissue interaction; not predominantly glycoproteins at the maternal-fetal interface.

questions.text: What are the histological components of Nitabuch's layer in the placental development?

choices.text: Trophoblastic cells and maternal blood vessels
It is a layer of fibrinoid degeneration of the outer syncytiotrophoblast

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) It is a layer of fibrinoid degeneration of the outer syncytiotrophoblast

Explanation:

  • Nitabuch’s Membrane is a layer of fibrinoid degeneration of the outer syncytiotrophoblast at the junction of the cytotrophoblastic shell and decidua,it prevents further deeper penetration of placenta into decidua basalis .
  • It is absent in conditions like placenta accreta, where there is abnormal placental adherence due to incomplete separation of the placenta from the uterine wall.

 

Trophoblastic cells and maternal blood vessels (Option A): Trophoblastic cells help form the placenta, and maternal blood vessels are found in the decidua basalis, but neither is a defining component of Nitabuch's membrane

Syncytiotrophoblast and cytotrophoblast layers (Option B) of cells make up the fetal portion of the placenta, primarily in the chorionic villi.

Chorionic villi and extravillous trophoblasts (Option D): Chorionic villi are finger-like projections of the placenta containing fetal blood vessels and extravillous trophoblasts, which invade maternal tissues, are integral to the placenta but not to Nitabuch's membrane.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic at 36 weeks gestation for a routine check-up. An ultrasound estimates the fetal weight to be 3,000 grams. The placenta is normal in structure and function without any abnormalities. Based on the ultrasound findings, what is the expected weight of the placenta at term?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 500 grams

 

Explanation:

 

At term, the average weight ratio of the placenta to the baby is approximately 1:6. From the given clinical scenario, with a fetal weight of 3,000 grams, the placenta would weigh around 500 grams.

  • weight ratio of the placenta to the baby is 1:1 around 17 weeks of gestation
  • At term, the placenta: 

    • Shape & Size: Circular disk, 15–20 cm in diameter, ~3 cm thick, thins at edges.

    • Weight & Position: Weighs ~500 g; covers ~30% of uterine wall.

    • Fetal Side:

      • Covered by smooth, shiny amnion.

      • Umbilical cord attached centrally with visible vessels.

    • Maternal Side:

      • Textured, sponge-like surface.

      • Divided into 15–20 cotyledons by decidual septa.

      • Each cotyledon contains a main villous stem with branches.

    • Attachment Site: Typically in the upper uterus, secured by anchoring villi and fused decidua capsularis + vera.

    • Separation After Birth: Detaches through the decidua spongiosum

    •

questions.text: During fetal development, which of the following accurately represents the time period of development of the tertiary villus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 21st day

 

Explanation:

  • Since Day 17 post-fertilization, as mentioned in Williams Textbook, isn't an option, select Day 21 instead, as per standard embryology textbooks.

  • The chorion is the outermost fetal membrane, made up of:

    • Outer trophoblast

    • Inner primitive mesenchyme

  • By early 3rd week: Syncytiotrophoblast forms primary stem villi.

  • By day 16: Mesodermal cells invade villi to form secondary villi.

  • By day 21: These cells differentiate into blood vessels, forming tertiary villi.

  • Later: Vascularized tertiary villi connect to the extraembryonic circulatory system.
